questions.question: What is Experience Cloud in Salesforce?

options.A: A developer-only framework for Apex-heavy sites.
options.B: A feature for internal reporting dashboards only.
options.C: A Salesforce product that allows organizations to create branded portals, partner communities, and customer self-service sites.
options.D: A lightweight mobile app builder unrelated to Salesforce communities.

questions.explanation: Experience Cloud enables orgs to build authenticated or public sites (customer/partner portals, help centers) with branding and community features.

questions.question: What are the different types of Experience Cloud sites?

options.A: Only internal admin portals and developer sandboxes.
options.B: Customer communities, partner communities, employee communities, B2B portals, and self-service help portals.
options.C: Only public marketing websites and blogs.
options.D: Only mobile-only microapps.

questions.explanation: Experience Cloud supports multiple site use-cases: customer support, partners, employees, B2B portals and self-service help.

questions.question: Difference between Customer Community and Partner Community?

options.A: Customer Community → For employees only; Partner Community → For customers only.
options.B: They are identical; only the name differs.
options.C: Customer Community → For end customers to log cases, access knowledge, and collaborate. Partner Community → For business partners to manage leads, opportunities, and deals.
options.D: Customer Community supports API access; Partner Community does not.

questions.explanation: Customer Communities focus on self-service/support; Partner Communities expose CRM objects like Leads/Opportunities for partner collaboration.

questions.question: What is the license difference between Customer and Partner Community?

options.A: Customer Community License → Includes full CRM access; Partner → limited to knowledge only.
options.B: Both licenses are identical in privileges.
options.C: Customer Community License → Focused on service/support use cases. Partner Community License → Includes CRM objects like Leads and Opportunities.
options.D: Licenses differ only by price, not features.

questions.explanation: Partner community licenses typically give access to CRM objects and sales features; customer licenses are optimized for support/self-service.

questions.question: What is the difference between Experience Cloud and Sites (Force.com Sites)?

options.A: Experience Cloud → Only for public marketing pages; Sites → supports communities and login.
options.B: They are exactly the same product rebranded.
options.C: Experience Cloud → Branded, customizable, authenticated or public. Force.com Sites → Public websites only, no login functionality.
options.D: Force.com Sites provides mobile widgets while Experience Cloud does not.

questions.explanation: Experience Cloud adds authenticated community features and builder tooling; Force.com Sites are for public, unauthenticated pages.

questions.question: How is Experience Cloud secured?

options.A: Only by IP restrictions; other controls aren't available.
options.B: Security is managed using profiles, permission sets, sharing sets, and role hierarchies.
options.C: Experience Cloud has no security controls; it's always public.
options.D: Only via SSO; profiles and permissions are ignored.

questions.explanation: Access for external users is controlled via standard Salesforce security primitives: profiles, permission sets, sharing sets, roles, and SSO options.

questions.question: What are Sharing Sets in Experience Cloud?

options.A: A method to duplicate records across orgs.
options.B: A way to share files only, not records.
options.C: Provide community users access to records related to their account or contact.
options.D: A deprecated feature replaced by Chatter groups.

questions.explanation: Sharing Sets map community (external) users to records related to their account/contact so they can access appropriate data without full role access.

questions.question: What is a Role Hierarchy in Partner Communities?

options.A: A method to schedule community publishing.
options.B: Defines how partner users can see and manage records within their partner organization.
options.C: A template for branding the site.
options.D: A required setting to enable CMS Connect.

questions.explanation: Partner role hierarchies model partner org structure, controlling record visibility and delegation among partner users.

questions.question: What is a Login & Registration page in Experience Cloud?

options.A: A page that only displays public marketing content.
options.B: The entry point where external users authenticate or sign up to access the portal.
options.C: A background service used for SSO token exchange only.
options.D: A deprecated Visualforce-only feature.

questions.explanation: The Login & Registration page handles authentication and self-registration flows for external community users.

questions.question: What authentication methods are available for Experience Cloud?

options.A: Only username/password stored in Salesforce.
options.B: No authentication is supported for Experience Cloud.
options.C: Salesforce login, Single Sign-On (SSO), Social Sign-On (Google, Facebook, LinkedIn).
options.D: Only OAuth client credentials flow is supported.

questions.explanation: Experience Cloud supports native Salesforce auth, SSO (SAML/OIDC), and social identity providers for convenient access.

questions.question: What is Delegated Authentication?

options.A: A way to delegate page layout control to community admins.
options.B: Allows an external system to validate user credentials instead of Salesforce.
options.C: A method for delegating records to queues.
options.D: A replacement for OAuth flows.

questions.explanation: Delegated authentication forwards credential validation to an external auth service rather than using Salesforce's internal auth.

questions.question: What is Just-in-Time (JIT) provisioning in Experience Cloud?

options.A: A batch job to sync users nightly.
options.B: Creates user records automatically during the first SSO login.
options.C: A manual user creation process by admins only.
options.D: A deprecated user management feature.

questions.explanation: JIT provisioning auto-creates and populates community user records upon successful SSO when the user does not already exist.

questions.question: What is Identity Provider (IdP) vs Service Provider (SP) in Experience Cloud?

options.A: IdP → System that serves content; SP → System that authenticates users.
options.B: They are the same role in SSO architecture.
options.C: IdP → System that authenticates users (e.g., Okta, Salesforce). SP → System that users access (Experience Cloud site).
options.D: IdP and SP are only used for SOAP integrations.

questions.explanation: In SSO, the IdP authenticates users while the SP (the Experience site) consumes the IdP's assertion to grant access.

questions.question: What is Branding in Experience Cloud?

options.A: Creating Apex classes for community pages.
options.B: Customizing the look and feel (logo, theme, colors, navigation) of a portal using Experience Builder.
options.C: A back-end security classification.
options.D: A process for migrating sites between orgs.

questions.explanation: Branding uses Experience Builder theme and settings to apply company logos, colors, and navigation for a consistent customer-facing experience.

questions.question: What is the Experience Builder?

options.A: A drag-and-drop tool to design and customize Experience Cloud sites without coding.
options.B: A command-line utility for site deployment only.
options.C: A mobile-only site editor.
options.D: A template engine for Apex email.

questions.explanation: Experience Builder provides a visual editor to compose pages, add components, and configure layout and navigation for a community site.

questions.question: Can LWC be used in Experience Cloud?

options.A: No — Experience Cloud only supports Aura components.
options.B: Yes, LWCs can be exposed as Lightning components and embedded into Experience Cloud pages.
options.C: Only Visualforce components are supported.
options.D: Only static HTML widgets are allowed.

questions.explanation: You can expose LWCs for use in Experience Builder and embed them into pages and templates for dynamic behavior.

questions.question: What are Audience Targeting rules in Experience Cloud?

options.A: A tool to throttle API calls by user profile.
options.B: Allow different page variations to be shown based on user profiles, location, or criteria.
options.C: A reporting filter for site visits only.
options.D: A deprecated feature replaced by permission sets.

questions.explanation: Audience targeting tailors the content and page variations presented to users based on attributes like profile, role, or custom criteria (correct content under B).

questions.question: What is a Navigation Menu in Experience Cloud?

options.A: Defines how users move between pages and features within the portal.
options.B: A low-level CSS file only.
options.C: A special object type for external data.
options.D: A repository of knowledge articles.

questions.explanation: Navigation menus are configured in Experience Builder to control site navigation, labels, and link targets for users.

questions.question: How are Knowledge Articles exposed in Experience Cloud?

options.A: By enabling Knowledge in the site and giving access to external users via permissions.
options.B: Knowledge cannot be exposed to Experience Cloud users.
options.C: Only by exporting articles to static pages.
options.D: Only via custom Apex pages.

questions.explanation: Configure article channels and permission sets to allow community users to search and view knowledge content in the portal.

questions.question: What are the types of Community users?

options.A: Only internal Salesforce users can access communities.
options.B: Customer Community User, Partner Community User, Customer Plus User, External App User.
options.C: Only Guest and Admin users exist.
options.D: Only Contact records can be community users.

questions.explanation: Experience Cloud supports various external user types with differing capabilities and license entitlements (customer, partner, plus, external app).

questions.question: What are Community Moderation features?

options.A: Flags, reputation points, and moderation rules to monitor and control user activity.
options.B: Only automated content deletion after 24 hours.
options.C: A tool to export comments to CSV daily.
options.D: A deprecated Chatter feature not available in Experience Cloud.

questions.explanation: Moderation tools help maintain community quality using flags, reputation/gamification and configurable moderation workflows.

questions.question: What are Reputation Levels in Experience Cloud?

options.A: A security clearance for admin users only.
options.B: A gamification feature that rewards users for participation (posting, commenting, answering).
options.C: A way to prioritize search results by date.
options.D: A deprecated metric no longer used.

questions.explanation: Reputation levels incentivize user contributions by granting badges/privileges as users engage in the community.

questions.question: What is the use of CMS Connect in Experience Cloud?

options.A: Integrates external CMS content (like WordPress, Drupal) into Experience Cloud.
options.B: A tool for connecting multiple Salesforce orgs.
options.C: A way to store static resources only.
options.D: A legacy API for file uploads.

questions.explanation: CMS Connect lets Experience sites surface content from external CMS platforms without importing content into Salesforce.

questions.question: How do you deploy an Experience Cloud site to production?

options.A: By copying HTML files via FTP to the production org.
options.B: Only by recreating the site manually in production.
options.C: By publishing the site in Experience Builder and deploying metadata using Change Sets or SFDX.
options.D: Experience Cloud sites cannot be deployed; they live only in sandbox.

questions.explanation: Publish changes in Experience Builder for content; move metadata (pages, components, site config) via Change Sets, SFDX, or metadata deploy tools.

questions.question: Best practices for Experience Cloud implementation?

options.A: Use sharing sets for simplified record access; optimize performance with caching; apply audience targeting for personalization; ensure strong authentication and branding.
options.B: Allow all external users full system access for convenience.
options.C: Avoid testing with real users; deploy immediately.
options.D: Use only Visualforce pages and avoid Experience Builder.

questions.explanation: Follow security and performance best practices: least-privilege access (sharing sets), caching, personalization, and robust authentication for external sites.
